question: Which of the following is true about a child with severe acute malnutrition?
exp: Diagnostic criteria for severe acute malnutrition in children between 6 months to 5 year age include: 1. Weight/height or Weight/length < -3 Z score, using the WHO Growth Standards 2. Presence of bipedal edema of nutritional origin 3. Mid- upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 115 mm Criteria for discharge of a child with severe acute malnutrition from hospital include: Child should have lost edema & staed gaining weight All infections & micro nutrient deficiencies should have been taken care of Child's appetite should have improved & he should be accepting well orally Mother should be confident of taking care of child at home
opa: His height for age should be < -3 z score
opb: His weight for age should be < -3 z score
opc: His weight for height should be < -3 z score
opd: His mid arm circumference should be < 13.5 cm

question: Which micronutrient deficiency can give rise to the following eye finding?
exp: ??' The given picture shows Bitot's spots, seen in Vitamin A deficiency. ??' Bitot's spots : Foamy appearance in conjunctiva due to superficial deposition of keratin in conjunctiva . Vitamin A deficiency (VAD), as graded by the WHO: Night blindness (XN) Conjunctival xerosis (X1A) Bitot's spots (X1B) Corneal xerosis (X2) Corneal ulcer covering less than 1/3 of the cornea (X3A) Corneal ulcer covering at least 1/3 of the cornea, defined as keratomalacia (X3B) Corneal scarring (XS) Xerophthalmic fundus (XF)

question: Corneal Xerosis corresponds to which stage of Xerophthalmia (As per as WHO)
exp: X2 is corneal xerosis as per as WHO classification of xerophthalmia

question: The following rashes seen in a previously well 5 month old child can be treated by administration of
exp: Deficiency of zinc leads to Acrodermatitis enteropathica -rashes seen especially around the orifices. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a genetic AR disorder Characterized by periorificial dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhea. Caused by mutations in the gene that encodes a membrane protein that binds zinc in the intestine. Treatment - Oral zinc supplementation

question: One of the following is false regarding complications of protein energy malnutrition:
exp: Hypoglycemia is a usual complication of malnutrition, not hyperglycemia.

question: All of the following are features of vitamin E deficiency EXCEPT:
exp: Vitamin E Deficiency: Loss of deep tendon reflexes Ataxia, dysahria Myopathy Neuropathy In premature infants- hemolytic anemia

question: Activity of glutathione reductase in RBCs gives an idea about functional index of which of the following?
exp: Activity of glutathione reductase in RBCs gives an idea about functional index of flavin coenzyme activity- Riboflavin

question: Casal necklace is seen in?
exp: Casal necklace is seen in: Pellagra Due to deficiency of Niacin / Vitamin B3. Tryptophan is used to produce niacin. Niacin deficiency occurs in hanup disease (defect in the transpoation of neutral amino acids) , maize-based diets and carcinoid syndrome. Characterised by 3Ds- Diarrhea, Dermatitis (Casal necklace), Dementia, and finally death.

question: All of the following are true about 'ready to use therapeutic food' (RUTF) EXCEPT?
exp: RUTF -energy dense, vitamin and mineral enriched food. Made of peanut paste, milk solids, sugar & oil. Good taste and is easy for the child to eat & digest. Each 100g contains 543 kcal. Avoid cumbersome preparation of recipes at home
opb: It contains peanut paste, milk solids & oil
opc: It is unpalatable and cannot be digested easily
opd: It helps avoid cumbersome preparation of recipes at home

question: A three day-old term infant borne at home, breast-fed exclusively, presented with lethargy, bulging fontanel, and bright red blood from rectum. What is the most likely etiology of his disease?
exp: Vit K deficiency is associated with hemorrhagic disease of newborn which has manifested in this baby as Intracranial hemorrhage (bulging fontanel) and GI bleed (blood per rectum). Moreover home delivery (Vit K may not have been given at bih) and exclusive breast feeding (Vit K is deficient in breast milk) clearly point to Vit K deficiency as etiology.

question: Which of the following indicate secondary failure to respond in a child with severe malnutrition?
exp: Primary failure to respond is indicated by- Failure to regain appetite by day 4 Failure to sta losing edema by day 4 Presence of edema on day 10 Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10 Secondary failure to respond is indicated by- Failure to gain at least 5g/kg/day for consecutive days during rehabilitation phase
opa: Failure to regain appetite by day 4
opc: Failure to gain at least 5g/kg/day for 3 consecutive days during the rehabilitation phase
opd: Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10

question: What is the most common underlying cause responsible for the disease in which this X ray finding is seen?
exp: The given X rays shows widening, cupping & fraying at metaphyseal ends of forearm bones- suggestive of Rickets Vitamin C deficiency- Pencil thin coex, Pelken spurs, Wimberger ring sign

question: This is seen due commonly due to deficiency of:
exp: * The given picture shows lesions at angles of mouth (angular cheilitis)- deficiency of vitamin B2 (Riboflavin). * Other features of vitamin B2 deficiency include glossitis, magenta tongue and geographic tongue . * Also have Corneal vascularisation * Image showing corneal vascularisation in vitamin B2 deficiency Cassal necklace--> niacin def. Acrodermatitis enteropathica--> zinc def. Xanthurenic aciduria--> Pyridoxine def.

question: What is the disease this child is suffering from?
exp: This child with severe malnutrition without edema is suffering from Marasmus. Kwashiorkor- edema present Rickets- child has pot belly Progeria- genetic condition- causes child to age fast

question: What is the abnormality shown in the hairs of a child with severe malnutrition?
exp: Alternate bands of pigmented & hypopigmented hairs seen in a child with malnutrition - 'Flag sign'.

question: 3 cardinal determinants of under nutrition are all except?
exp: 3 cardinal determinants of under nutrition: Low bih weight Infections Low food intake

question: Sodium content of ReSoMal is:
exp: ReSoMAL (Rehydration solution for severely Malnourished child): Severely malnourished children are deficient in potassium and have relatively high levels of sodium ReSoMal- lower sodium concentration and higher potassium concentration. Component ReSoMal (mEq/L) WHO ORS (mEq/L) Glucose 125 75 Sodium 45 75 Potassium 40 20 Chloride 70 65 Citrate 7 10 Magnesium 3 Zinc 0.3 Copper 0.045 Osmolarity 300 245

question: In severe acute malnutrition, hypoglycemia is defined as?
exp: In severe acute malnutrition, hypoglycemia is defined as: Blood glucose level <54 mg/dl For correction ofasymptomatichypoglycemia,50 mlof 10% glucose or sucrose solution should be given orally or by nasogastric tube. For correction ofsymptomatichypoglycemia,5 ml/kgof 10% dextrose should be given intravenously. This should be followed with 50 ml of 10% dextrose or sucrose solution by nasogastric tube. Hypoglycemia, hypothermia and infection generally occur as a triad in SAM.

question: All of the following are used to assess the mid-upper arm circumference except?
exp: Harpenden calliper is used to measure skinfold thickness which is an indication of subcutaneous fat. The other three are used to measure the mid-upper arm circumference. The Shakir tape is used to measure mid-upper arm circumference. It has three coloured zones corresponding to various levels of wasting * In bangle test, a bangle with an internal diameter of 4 cm is passed above the elbow. In severe malnutrition, it can be passed above the elbow, in normal children it cannot. * QUACK stick - Quaker arm circumference measuringstick. It is a measure of expected Mid-arm circumference that would be expected for a given height

question: Which of the following are the qualities of a green light food as per traffic light diet plan for children?
exp: The "traffic light" diet groups food as: Category Characteristics Recommended Intake Examples Red High in calories, sugar, and fat Reserved for infrequent treats Fatty meats, sugar, sweet beverages, fried foods Yellow Nutrient-dense, but higher in calories & fat In moderation Lean meats, dairy, starches, grains Green Low-calorie, high-fiber, low-fat, nutrient-dense Without any limitations Fruits, vegetables
opa: Nutrition dense, but higher In calories and fat
opb: Low calories, high fibre, low fat. Nutrition-dense
opc: High in calories. sugar and fat

question: All of the following are Vitamin B6 dependent syndromes, EXCEPT:
exp: Darier disease- autosomal dominant, characterized by greasy hyperkeratotic papules in seborrheic regions, nail abnormalities, and mucous membrane changes. Vitamin B6 dependence syndromes syndromes : pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy, a vitamin B6-responsive anemia, xanthurenic aciduria, cystathioninuria, and homocystinuria.

question: All of the following are true about 'POSHAN' abhiyaan except?
exp: POSHAN' abhiyaan- 'PM's Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nutrition'. Launched by Prime minister in March 2018. The focus is on health and nutrition in first 1000 days of life. The goals for this program include reduction in stunting, undernutrition & low bih weight by 2% per annum and anemia in young children by 3% per annum.
opa: Launched by Prime minister in March 2018
opb: It is PM's overarching scheme for holistic nutrition
opc: The focus is on health and nutrition in first 2000 days of life
opd: Goals for this program include reduction in stunting, undernutrition, low bih weight and anemia

question: Deficiency of which element can lead to syndrome of growth failure, anemia and hypogonadism?
exp: Deficiency of zinc can lead to syndrome of growth failure, anemia and hypogonadism.

question: What is this device used by health workers to assess nutritional status of under-5 children?
exp: This device used by health workers to assess nutritional status of under-5 children - Shakir's tape Used to measure mid upper arm circumference (MUAC) Red zone- severe malnutrition Yellow zone- mild to moderate malnutrition Green zone- normal

question: In a 3 year old baby, all of the following can be used as a criteria for diagnosis of Severe acute malnutrition EXCEPT?
exp: Diagnostic criteria for severe acute malnutrition in children between 6 months to 5 year age include: 1. Weight/height or Weight/length < -3 Z score, using the WHO Growth Standards 2. Presence of bipedal edema of nutritional origin 3. Mid- upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 115 mm
opa: Weight/height < -3 Z score, using the WHO Growth chas
opb: Presence of bipedal edema of nutritional origin

question: First clinical sign of vitamin A deficiency:
exp: First clinical sign of vitamin A deficiency is conjunctival xerosis, while 1st symptom is night blindness.

question: A child with diarrhoea since 2 days shows the following sign. It is said to be very slow when it takes?
exp: Skin pinch test -assess severity of dehydration in patients with diarrhoea. Pinch the skin on dorsum of hand or on abdomen- show skin turgor. If skin goes back quickly- normal hydration. If skin goes back slowly(<2 sec but not immediately)- moderate dehydration. If skin goes back very slowly (>2 sec) - severe dehydration. No Dehydration Some Dehydration Severe Dehydration Consciousness Ale "Irritable" "Lethargic" Eyes Normal Sunken Very sunken Thirst Normal "drinks eagerly" "Unable to drink" Buccal mucosa Normal Dry Very dry Skin pinch Goes back quickly "Slowly" "Very slowly" Tears Present Absent Absent Treatment Plan a Plan b Plan c

question: Kwashiorkor is diagnosed in growth retarded children along with:
exp: Kwashiorkor: Malnutrition with poor appetite Edema Mental changes- apathy, lethargy Others- flaky paint dermatosis, flag sign

question: The following statement about Gomez classification is false:
exp: Gomez classification is based on weight for age criteria
opd: This classification has prognostic value for hospitalization of children.

question: Decrease in weight for height indicates?
exp: Decrease in weight for height indicates Acute malnutrition Decrease in height for age indicates chronic malnutrition.
